rows.title: 1: The Contradictions of Being Asian American
rows.description: For our first episode, katie and Nicole discuss their Chinese to American ratio with their parents, Jiming and Li, who also shared their perspective on raising kids in America. katie and Nicole discuss the contradictions of being Asian American, both as a model minority and persistent other. The Book and Essay Club kicks off with Erika Lee's "The Making of Asian America." On Hella Asian, Nicole investigates the ubiquity of the Danish cookie tins.
rows.itunessubtitle: katie and Nicole talk to their parents, Jiming and Li, about their Chinese to American ratio. The Book and Essay Club kicks off with Erika Lee's "The Making of Asian America." On Hella Asian, Nicole investigates the ubiquity of the Danish cookie tins.

rows.title: 2: Swintoning
rows.description: This week, katie and Nicole dive into diversity in Hollywood, centered on a discussion of Margaret Cho and Tilda Swinton’s quest for racial absolution. On the new Can We Not segment: Rappers who only shout out Asian women with references to Chinese takeout... can we not? And you'll hear some tips and tricks about food storage on Hella Asian.
rows.itunessubtitle: We discuss diversity in Hollywood and analyze the Tilda Swinton emails to Margaret Cho. Can we not only shoutout Asian women in rap with references to Chinese takeout? On Hella Asian, learn some tips and tricks for leveling up your food storage game.

rows._xml: <entry><id>https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds/list/1Yz_fEijAModseWuUnaW0a4_IqNGYksNzC6qx2SwLA2k/od6/public/values/chk2m</id><updated>2017-05-30T22:11:57.330Z</updated><category scheme='http://schemas.google.com/spreadsheets/2006' term='http://schemas.google.com/spreadsheets/2006#list'/><title type='text'>3: Exploring Culture Through Art</title><content type='text'>description: On this week's episode, Felicia Liang joins us for a conversation on art, culture, and everything in between. rows.title: 3: Exploring Culture Through Art
rows.description: On this week's episode, Felicia Liang joins us for a conversation on art, culture, and everything in between. We talk about her #100daysians project, her creative process, and what's next. On Hella Asian, Felicia flexes her abacus skills and we bond over the shared burden of weekend Chinese school. Can We Not Steve Harvey? katie and Nicole dive into the TV personality's offensive remarks about Asian American men.
rows.itunessubtitle: Felicia Liang of #100daysians joins us for a conversation on art, culture, and more. On Hella Asian, Felicia flexes her abacus skills. Can We Not, Steve Harvey? katie and Nicole dive into his offensive remarks about Asian American men.

rows._xml: <entry><id>https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds/list/1Yz_fEijAModseWuUnaW0a4_IqNGYksNzC6qx2SwLA2k/od6/public/values/ciyn3</id><updated>2017-05-30T22:11:57.330Z</updated><category scheme='http://schemas.google.com/spreadsheets/2006' term='http://schemas.google.com/spreadsheets/2006#list'/><title type='text'>4: The Racialization of Popchips</title><content type='text'>description: This week, we hang out with Priya Krishnakumar, a visual journalist at the LA Times. We talk to Priya about her overachieving parents, her insecurities as an Indian American, and she gives us her take on the state South Asians in Hollywood. We also swoon over Dev Patel and roast Ashton Kutcher for racializing Popchips. On Hella Asian, Priya recounts the power of a ganesha doll in exterminating pests. On IRL, Nicole recaps a panel on the Asian American community's needs in the time of Trump. ScarJo... Can We Not?, url: http://bumpers.fm/e/b2lludm713n002v9lgg0.m4a, date: February 20, 2017, itunesauthor: katie zhu and Nicole Zhu, itunessubtitle: Priya Krishnakumar, a visual journalist at the LA Times, talks about her Indian American identity, South Asian representation in pop culture, and more. On IRL, Nicole recaps a political panel and ScarJo: Can We Not perpetuate white feminism?, itunesimage: http://sweetandsour.fm/feed/assets/img/episode4.png, itunesduration: 28:01, guid: sweet-and-sour-episode4.m4a, bytelength: 25892271</content><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds/list/1Yz_fEijAModseWuUnaW0a4_IqNGYksNzC6qx2SwLA2k/od6/public/values/ciyn3'/><gsx:title>4: The Racialization of Popchips</gsx:title><gsx:description>This week, we hang out with Priya Krishnakumar, a visual journalist at the LA Times. We also swoon over Dev Patel and roast Ashton Kutcher for racializing Popchips. On Hella Asian, Priya recounts the power of a ganesha doll in exterminating pests. On IRL, Nicole recaps a panel on the Asian American community's needs in the time of Trump. ScarJo... Can We Not?</gsx:description><gsx:url>http://bumpers.fm/e/b2lludm713n002v9lgg0.m4a</gsx:url><gsx:date>February 20, 2017</gsx:date><gsx:itunesauthor>katie zhu and Nicole Zhu</gsx:itunesauthor><gsx:itunessubtitle>Priya Krishnakumar, a visual journalist at the LA Times, talks about her Indian American identity, South Asian representation in pop culture, and more. On IRL, Nicole recaps a political panel and ScarJo: Can We Not perpetuate white feminism?</gsx:itunessubtitle><gsx:itunesimage>http://sweetandsour.fm/feed/assets/img/episode4.png</gsx:itunesimage><gsx:itunesduration>28:01</gsx:itunesduration><gsx:guid>sweet-and-sour-episode4.m4a</gsx:guid><gsx:bytelength>25892271</gsx:bytelength></entry>
rows.title: 4: The Racialization of Popchips
rows.description: This week, we hang out with Priya Krishnakumar, a visual journalist at the LA Times. We talk to Priya about her overachieving parents, her insecurities as an Indian American, and she gives us her take on the state South Asians in Hollywood. We also swoon over Dev Patel and roast Ashton Kutcher for racializing Popchips. On Hella Asian, Priya recounts the power of a ganesha doll in exterminating pests. On IRL, Nicole recaps a panel on the Asian American community's needs in the time of Trump. ScarJo... Can We Not?
rows.itunessubtitle: Priya Krishnakumar, a visual journalist at the LA Times, talks about her Indian American identity, South Asian representation in pop culture, and more. On IRL, Nicole recaps a political panel and ScarJo: Can We Not perpetuate white feminism?

rows._xml: <entry><id>https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds/list/1Yz_fEijAModseWuUnaW0a4_IqNGYksNzC6qx2SwLA2k/od6/public/values/ckd7g</id><updated>2017-05-30T22:11:57.330Z</updated><category scheme='http://schemas.google.com/spreadsheets/2006' term='http://schemas.google.com/spreadsheets/2006#list'/><title type='text'>5: You Need Less Face</title><content type='text'>description: Elise Hu joins us this week as Sweet and Sour's first foreign correspondent. Elise works for NPR and is based in Seoul. We talk to her about gender stereotypes in Korea and Japan, discuss Asian fetish and its ~consequences~, and what it's like to raise biracial kids in the time of Trump. We talk to her about gender stereotypes in Korea and Japan, discuss Asian fetish and its ~consequences~, and her experience raising biracial children.</gsx:itunessubtitle><gsx:itunesimage>http://sweetandsour.fm/feed/assets/img/episode5.png</gsx:itunesimage><gsx:itunesduration>36:45</gsx:itunesduration><gsx:guid>sweet-and-sour-episode5.m4a</gsx:guid><gsx:bytelength>34195139</gsx:bytelength></entry>
rows.title: 5: You Need Less Face
rows.description: Elise Hu joins us this week as Sweet and Sour's first foreign correspondent. Elise works for NPR and is based in Seoul. We talk to her about gender stereotypes in Korea and Japan, discuss Asian fetish and its ~consequences~, and what it's like to raise biracial kids in the time of Trump. On Hella Asian, Elise shares her love of Asian convenience stores.
rows.itunessubtitle: Elise Hu joins us as Sweet and Sour's first foreign correspondent. Elise works for NPR in Seoul. We talk to her about gender stereotypes in Korea and Japan, discuss Asian fetish and its ~consequences~, and her experience raising biracial children.

rows._xml: <entry><id>https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds/list/1Yz_fEijAModseWuUnaW0a4_IqNGYksNzC6qx2SwLA2k/od6/public/values/clrrx</id><updated>2017-05-30T22:11:57.330Z</updated><category scheme='http://schemas.google.com/spreadsheets/2006' term='http://schemas.google.com/spreadsheets/2006#list'/><title type='text'>6: Of Bananas and Coconuts</title><content type='text'>description: Preetisha Sen joins us on the pod this week, a proud coconut—brown on the outside, white on the inside. Preetisha talks to us about growing up Indian American, why being Asian American doesn't mean she's always in a constant identity crisis, and how she thinks about religion through her experiences with Hinduism and Christianity. She also shares a Hella Indian story about her family on this week's Hella Asian. Plus: Can We Not... always assume the Asian woman is the nanny? kthx., url: http://bumpers.fm/e/b38d1aqtm1a0010nvk40.m4a, date: March 21, 2017, itunesauthor: katie zhu and Nicole Zhu, itunessubtitle: Preetisha Sen, a proud coconut (brown on the outside white on the inside), discusses religion & tells us why being Asian American doesn't mean constant identity crisis. She shares a Hella Indian story, plus: Can We Not assume an Asian woman is the nanny?, itunesimage: http://sweetandsour.fm/feed/assets/img/episode6.png, itunesduration: 27:42, guid: sweet-and-sour-episode6.m4a, bytelength: 25234851</content><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds/list/1Yz_fEijAModseWuUnaW0a4_IqNGYksNzC6qx2SwLA2k/od6/public/values/clrrx'/><gsx:title>6: Of Bananas and Coconuts</gsx:title><gsx:description>Preetisha Sen joins us on the pod this week, a proud coconut—brown on the outside, white on the inside. Preetisha talks to us about growing up Indian American, why being Asian American doesn't mean she's always in a constant identity crisis, and how she thinks about religion through her experiences with Hinduism and Christianity. She also shares a Hella Indian story about her family on this week's Hella Asian. Plus: Can We Not... always assume the Asian woman is the nanny? kthx.</gsx:description><gsx:url>http://bumpers.fm/e/b38d1aqtm1a0010nvk40.m4a</gsx:url><gsx:date>March 21, 2017</gsx:date><gsx:itunesauthor>katie zhu and Nicole Zhu</gsx:itunesauthor><gsx:itunessubtitle>Preetisha Sen, a proud coconut (brown on the outside white on the inside), discusses religion & tells us why being Asian American doesn't mean constant identity crisis. She shares a Hella Indian story, plus: Can We Not assume an Asian woman is the nanny?</gsx:itunessubtitle><gsx:itunesimage>http://sweetandsour.fm/feed/assets/img/episode6.png</gsx:itunesimage><gsx:itunesduration>27:42</gsx:itunesduration><gsx:guid>sweet-and-sour-episode6.m4a</gsx:guid><gsx:bytelength>25234851</gsx:bytelength></entry>
rows.title: 6: Of Bananas and Coconuts
rows.description: Preetisha Sen joins us on the pod this week, a proud coconut—brown on the outside, white on the inside. Preetisha talks to us about growing up Indian American, why being Asian American doesn't mean she's always in a constant identity crisis, and how she thinks about religion through her experiences with Hinduism and Christianity. She also shares a Hella Indian story about her family on this week's Hella Asian. Plus: Can We Not... always assume the Asian woman is the nanny? kthx.
rows.itunessubtitle: Preetisha Sen, a proud coconut (brown on the outside white on the inside), discusses religion & tells us why being Asian American doesn't mean constant identity crisis. She shares a Hella Indian story, plus: Can We Not assume an Asian woman is the nanny?

rows._xml: <entry><id>https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds/list/1Yz_fEijAModseWuUnaW0a4_IqNGYksNzC6qx2SwLA2k/od6/public/values/cyevm</id><updated>2017-05-30T22:11:57.330Z</updated><category scheme='http://schemas.google.com/spreadsheets/2006' term='http://schemas.google.com/spreadsheets/2006#list'/><title type='text'>7: The Origins of the Model Minority Myth</title><content type='text'>description: Ellen Wu joins us this week to discuss her book, "The Color of Success: Asian Americans and the Origins of the Model Minority."  Ellen breaks down Asian American history from the 1920s onward, analyzing the contradiction of the model minority myth being rooted in both inclusion and exclusion. We dive into race-making, geopolitical dimensions of Asian American identity, and the effect of the model minority on other groups such as Blacks, Latinx, South Asian and Southeast Asians. Ellen also unpacks the role that Asian American communities played in the formation of their own stereotypes., url: http://bumpers.fm/e/b3qgqnd75hag010dsg20.m4a, date: April 17, 2017, itunesauthor: katie zhu and Nicole Zhu, itunessubtitle: Ellen Wu joins us to discuss her book, "The Color of Success: Asian Americans & the Origins of the Model Minority." We unpack the effect of the model minority on other groups and the role of Asian Americans in the formation of their own stereotypes., itunesimage: http://sweetandsour.fm/feed/assets/img/episode7.png, itunesduration: 40:38, guid: sweet-and-sour-episode7.m4a, bytelength: 35022886</content><link rel='self' type='application/atom+xml' href='https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds/list/1Yz_fEijAModseWuUnaW0a4_IqNGYksNzC6qx2SwLA2k/od6/public/values/cyevm'/><gsx:title>7: The Origins of the Model Minority Myth</gsx:title><gsx:description>Ellen Wu joins us this week to discuss her book, "The Color of Success: Asian Americans and the Origins of the Model Minority."  Ellen breaks down Asian American history from the 1920s onward, analyzing the contradiction of the model minority myth being rooted in both inclusion and exclusion. We dive into race-making, geopolitical dimensions of Asian American identity, and the effect of the model minority on other groups such as Blacks, Latinx, South Asian and Southeast Asians. Ellen also unpacks the role that Asian American communities played in the formation of their own stereotypes.</gsx:description><gsx:url>http://bumpers.fm/e/b3qgqnd75hag010dsg20.m4a</gsx:url><gsx:date>April 17, 2017</gsx:date><gsx:itunesauthor>katie zhu and Nicole Zhu</gsx:itunesauthor><gsx:itunessubtitle>Ellen Wu joins us to discuss her book, "The Color of Success: Asian Americans & the Origins of the Model Minority." We unpack the effect of the model minority on other groups and the role of Asian Americans in the formation of their own stereotypes.</gsx:itunessubtitle><gsx:itunesimage>http://sweetandsour.fm/feed/assets/img/episode7.png</gsx:itunesimage><gsx:itunesduration>40:38</gsx:itunesduration><gsx:guid>sweet-and-sour-episode7.m4a</gsx:guid><gsx:bytelength>35022886</gsx:bytelength></entry>
rows.title: 7: The Origins of the Model Minority Myth
rows.description: Ellen Wu joins us this week to discuss her book, "The Color of Success: Asian Americans and the Origins of the Model Minority."  Ellen breaks down Asian American history from the 1920s onward, analyzing the contradiction of the model minority myth being rooted in both inclusion and exclusion. We dive into race-making, geopolitical dimensions of Asian American identity, and the effect of the model minority on other groups such as Blacks, Latinx, South Asian and Southeast Asians. Ellen also unpacks the role that Asian American communities played in the formation of their own stereotypes.
rows.itunessubtitle: Ellen Wu joins us to discuss her book, "The Color of Success: Asian Americans & the Origins of the Model Minority." We unpack the effect of the model minority on other groups and the role of Asian Americans in the formation of their own stereotypes.

rows.title: 8: Eat Bitter
rows.description: Jason Shen joins us this week to discuss the Asian American Man Study, an annual survey of the experiences and perspectives of American men of East, Southeast, and South Asian descent. Jason breaks down the 2016 results, discussing demographics, race and identity, stereotypes, media, dating, politics, and religion. We also chat about his views on masculinity as an Asian American man. On Hella Asian, Jason brings up an hot button issue: shoe-free households.
rows.itunessubtitle: Jason Shen discusses the results of the 2016 Asian American Man Study, an annual survey of East, Southeast, and South Asian American men. We chat identity, stereotypes, and masculinity. On Hella Asian, Jason espouses shoe-free households.

Kaitlin shares her experience as an Asian woman in technology and tells us about how Flawless Hacks started. We discuss her passion for education and how she’s shaped Flawless Hacks to be a collaborative, non-competitive space for women in technology. rows.title: 9: Creating Spaces for Women of Color in Tech
rows.description: We chat with Kaitlin Gu, a software engineer at Google and the cofounder of Flawless Hacks, an annual Beyoncé-themed hackathon for women by women. Kaitlin shares her experience as an Asian woman in technology and tells us about how Flawless Hacks started. We discuss her passion for education and how she’s shaped Flawless Hacks to be a collaborative, non-competitive space for women in technology. On Hella Asian, we swap dating expectations our Asian parents have for us.
rows.itunessubtitle: We chat with Kaitlin Gu, a software engineer at Google and cofounder of Flawless Hacks. She shares her experience as an Asian woman in technology and her passion for education. On Hella Asian, we swap parents’ dating expectations.
